questions.text: Anterior dislocation of the shoulder is likely to result in the damage of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
• Axillary nerve injury is a common complication after anterior dislocation of shoulder as the nerve wind around the neck of humerus and will be stretched whenever the humeral head goes out of the glenoid.
  • Deltoid muscle palsy: abduction of shoulder lost
  • Sensory supply : lateral cutaneous nerve of arm branch of axillary nerve leading to anesthesia over skin over the deltoid- regimental badge sign

Anterior dislocation of shoulder can also be associated with musculocuatneous nerve injury

Musculocutaneous nerve supplies- biceps, brachialis, coracobrachialis, so in this nerve injury supination and flexion of elbow is lost

Musculocutaneous nerve continues as lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm

OPTION C IS INCORRECT-Radial nerve is injured after spiral mid shaft humerus fracture

OPTION B IS INCORRECT -Median nerve is injured during medial epicondyle humerus fracture.

(D) Suprascapular nerve - Incorrect

  • The suprascapular nerve innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles and passes through the suprascapular notch.
  • It is more commonly injured due to compression at the suprascapular notch or spinoglenoid notch, rather than shoulder dislocations.

Reference:Rockwood and greens fracture in adults 9thedition page no.1069

choices.text: Posterior dislocation of hip has flexion and adduction
Vessel injury more common in anterior
Nerve injury more common in anterior
Posterior dislocation is more common than anterior

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hip dislocation?
questions.solution:
Nerve injury is more common in posterior hip dislocation.

Sciatic nerve is injured in posterior hip dislocation.

Rest all options are correct.

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 5thedition page no 130

questions.text: Most common pattern of Pott's spine involvement is?
questions.solution:
There are 4 patterns of vertebral involvement in Pott's spine:

  1. Paradiscal (due to arterial spread):- This is the commonest  In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.
  2. Central (due to venous spread):- In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal.
  3. Anterior (due to subperiosteal spread):- In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  4. Appendiceal and posterior type (occur in isolation involving pedicles, laminae, transverse process and spinous process or in conjunction with typical paradiscal variant).

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 183.

questions.text: 60 years old patient presents with limping gait and right hip pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-ray shows loss of sphericity of femoral head

Collapse of weight bearing area of femoral head

Sclerosis of femoral head

AVN of femoral head (chandler's disease)

  • Avascular necrosis of femoral head leading to collapse and deformation of femoral head leading to osteoarthritis
  • Mechanism: increased intraosseous pressure leading to blockage of blood supply
  • Risk factors:
    • Idiopathic (most common)
    • Trauma
    • Steroid use
    • Alcohol use
    • Antiretrovirals
    • Gaucher's disease
    • Caisson's disease
    • Blood anomalies: sickle cell disease, thrombophilia, protein C deficiency, protein S deficiency
  • Clinical features: males>females
    • Bilateral presentation with steroid use present in 80 % cases
    • Pain
    • Limping gait
    • Restriction of abduction and internal rotation
    • Sectoral sign positive: differential rotation of hip due to alteration in shape of femoral head
  • Investigation:
    • Investigation of choice: MRI (double density sign)
    • X-ray shows sclerosis, fragmentation, collapse (crescent sign)
  • FICART AND ARLET classification for AVN of femoral head (crescent sign seen in stage 2b of this classification)
  • Treatment: stop steroids if taking, bisphophonates, core depression with vascularised fibular graft, if osteoarthritis has developed -total hip replacement is the last resort

Other Options:

A)TB Hip: Slow progression, systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss), joint destruction on X-ray.

B)Rheumatoid Arthritis: Bilateral joint involvement, morning stiffness, systemic inflammation.

C)Ankylosing Spondylitis: Back pain, spinal stiffness, bilateral sacroiliitis, not isolated hip pain.

Reference: Maheshwari book of orthopedics 7th edition pg no 131

questions.text: A 10-year-old child comes with a swelling in the tibial diaphysis, xray shows reaction on the surface of the bone, biopsy of the lesion shows small round cells and mic2 mutation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of Ewing's sarcoma are:
1. Age: Ewing's is the most common bone tumour of first decade of life.
2. Site -Ewing's sarcoma arises from the diaphysis
3. Biopsy finding of round blue cells with pseudorosettes is a feature of Ewing's
4. MIC 2 positive cells, translocation (11:22) are diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma
5.Markers of Ewing sarcoma: MIC2 (CD99) +ve, PAS +ve, diastase resistant

The characteristic x ray finding of Ewing's sarcoma is the Onion peel periosteal reaction.

Current treatment for Ewing' s sarcoma include neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy.
Only in "unresectable" tumors, or situations where resection would be associated with poor functional outcome would Ewing's be treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy without surgical excision. Ewing sarcoma is the most radiosensitive malignant bone tumor
Genetics in bone tumors

Reference: Maheshwari ortho 7th edition page no 236.
